content: Under the Impoundment Control Act of 1974, the President can propose to rescind funding from an appropriations act by sending a special message to Congress. An Administration draft bill, titled the Legislative Line Item Veto Act of 2006 (LLIVA), was transmitted to Congress on March 6, 2006. The bill proposed "expedited rescission" which requires at least one house to vote on the President's proposals for rescissions. If either house disapproves, the other house need not take action, as approval by both houses is necessary to make the rescission permanent. This contrasts with the "enhanced rescission" provision under the Line Item Veto Act of 1996. The "enhanced rescission" provision under the Line Item Veto Act of 1996 altered the rescission framework to create a presumption favoring the President. A draft bill in 2006, titled the Legislative Line Item Veto Act, proposed new provisions for the President to propose rescissions in a special message to Congress. The Veto Act of 2006, known as H.R. 4890 and S. 2381, proposed amendments to the 1974 ICA framework by introducing a new "Legislative Line Item Veto" allowing the President to propose rescissions of discretionary budget authority, direct spending items, or targeted tax benefits in a special message to Congress. The President would have flexibility in submitting multiple rescissions without time constraints or limitations on the number of rescissions in a single message. The Legislative Line Item Veto Act (LLIVA) would grant the President flexibility in submitting and packaging special messages for rescissions without time constraints. Rescission requests would be considered under fast-track procedures, with adjustments to committee allocations and spending caps required within five days of enactment. Supporters argue that this mechanism is necessary to give Congress time to consider a rescission proposal before an extended recess. Critics argue that the 180-day withholding mechanism in the LLIVA bill could be abused and is unnecessary, as the expedited procedures usually result in a final vote on the President's request within a month.
